column4: what command would I use to mount a samba share overtop my existing file system?
I just want to mix my mounted /bin with my actual /bin etc
wow this room is full I don't see how anyone can carry on a conversation in this lol
what command would I use to mount a samba share overtop my existing file system?
so any not so busy channel I could go to for my question, the ##linux channel only has a few people none of which are answering
trying to add permanently or temproarily an SMB FS?
whichever is easiest :)
I would prefer permanent
have you setup an entry for the fs in fstab?
if you do, you can automount it every time
yea, but I want it to overlay my existing filesystem and I am not sure how to do that one
when you say "overlay the existing stuff" - I am not following - sorry
ok I will try to explain, as I am not sure what the correct terminology is

basically my mount has an etc and a bin folder with a bunch of stuff in it. When I mount it I want the stuff in the mounted etc and bin folder to be merged with the stuff in my filesystems /etc and /bin folder
do you understand?
was trying to chat privately - but don't think that will happen - that's asking sambe to make two filesystems one on two different mount points
mount points tell the kernel what files are, where they are located etc. and Samba won't merge files like that AFAIK
from what I was told it is possible, if samba won't mount it like that afayk then how would I go about achieving the same affect with symlinks?

I am not sure - I am not aware of mounting two drives into one filesystem dynamically for the /etc/ and /bin directories though Samba, nor am I sure what would be the point of doing that. What is it that this would give you?
OK - I'd suggest someone else as the best expert then, I haven't played around with JEOS version of Ubuntu a'tall

alright, thanks though. btw I am definitely not using jeos...it is FAR too large. I just came here because it is a general linux question with a specific application and the ubuntu folks are really good at helping people out
